Hello Dragonslayers and Families,

We are excited to announce that since the state has lowered its restrictions to yellow, we can now hold some activities at the school (As long as we follow state guidelines). These activities will be held at the school starting next week and will be held weekly until July 31, 2020.

In order to maintain safety, we do need all students to adhere to the following:

1. Please take your temperature at home before coming into the building. If you have a fever, or if you are displaying any symptoms of COVID-19, please remain home until symptoms are gone.

2. Please maintain social distancing of 6 feet.

3. Masks are encouraged but not required.

We hope to see you there!

post_text: It's been quite a day at SGA. Not only did our students complete their first day of finals, but our incredible community outreach student committee made a huge humanitarian donation to The Learning Center for Families. SGA students wanted to share the gift of literacy this holiday season and began a "youth-read-athon" drive where they collected children and young adult books from their homes. They partnered with local children's author Susan Hancock, whose publisher donated over $15,000 worth of books to the families of TLC. Our SGA community also collected food, clothing, diapers, blankets, pillows, and beanies. If that wasn't enough several students and their friends stayed after the delivery to assemble newborn kits as well. Our students were interviewed on 102.3 Coyote FM, Kool 98.9 FM, and Mix 103.1 FM We are SO proud of their efforts and the impact their generosity and goodwill will have on our community and the world at large.

Had the most beautiful spring-like day today at The Academy. These flowers and trees were planted last fall and are now getting ready to burst forth with the life of a new season.

Now for some plant philosophy: We have always planned for the grounds at SGA to serve as a learning environment and already we are reminded of one of the first lessons Mother Nature gives us. What you sow and carefully tend to, will give abundant reward. We've had a lot of bleak, stormy, cold winter weather. If given what they need all these plants pictured come back stronger and more vigorous after a period of vernalization (cold harsh weather.) Sometimes life gives us challenging circumstances, but if we endure them we are made better equipped to thrive in our lives. At St. George Academy our goal is not merely to give information to students, but to help them learn to approach and relish challenge; to equip them with confidence and skills that we hope will serve them abundantly in their future lives.

An interesting piece from this morning's Journal...

As the disconnect between the high school experience and the college's expectations continues to grow, universities are starting to change what they look for in the students they offer admissions to. Many schools no longer require pre-admission tests like the ACT. According to this article, some top-tier universities will no longer offer credit for AP courses citing that even though students may perform well in these courses and on the AP exams, they are still unprepared for the university experience.

This reality is more confirmation that public education's model of industrial schooling is failing to adequately achieve its stated goals and students are increasingly being left unprepared. If high school isn't preparing its students, what exactly is it doing? Saint George Academy is built on the premise that the purpose of an education is an education and our mission is to prepare our students for success at tomorrow's universities.

As the disconnect between the high school experience and the college's expectations continues to grow, universities are starting to change what they look for in the students they offer admissions to. Many schools no longer require pre-admission tests like the ACT. According to this article, some top-tier universities will no longer offer credit for AP courses citing that even though students may perform well in these courses and on the AP exams, they are still unprepared for the university experience.

This reality is more confirmation that public education's model of industrial schooling is failing to adequately achieve its stated goals and students are increasingly being left unprepared. If high school isn't preparing its students, what exactly is it doing? Saint George Academy is built on the premise that the purpose of an education is an education and our mission is to prepare our students for success at tomorrow's universities.

The Academy is building its faculty.

The key to SGA's success will be the work of its highly qualified faculty. Core members have already been recruited and candidates from across the nation are inquiring about positions for this incredible professional opportunity.

The SGA Administration is seeking more local candidates for consideration. Full time and part time positions are available.
Positions are still being sought for the the following content areas:

Social and Behavioral Sciences
English and Language Arts
Science and Mathematics

In addition, individuals with foreign language teaching experience, and career and technical education (CTE) are in high demand to immediately expand the elective curriculum of SGA's academic programs.

If you, or anyone you know, is interested in serving as a faculty member with St. George please have them contact David Jones, Executive Director at djones@stgacademy.org.

It is with an incredible amount of excitement, and relief, that I am able to share with you that we received our last and final vote today from the State Charter Board allowing us to open our doors for 2016! You are the first to know! This is a huge accomplishment in the life of St. George Academy and one that has taken an amazing amount of work. 12 schools started in this process over a year ago, 5 schools made it through. This is fantastic news for our families and education as a whole in Southern Utah.

Please share this information with friends, family, or whomever you know that has an interest in the quality of education we wish for our children.

Thank you again for your interest in St. George Academy. I will see you all next week, Wednesday evening, 5:30 pm, at the informational evening hosted by George Washington Academy.

With relief,

Stephen Wattles
President, Board of Directors
St. George Academy
